newsitem.title: USA: ATHLETICS-SUPERSTARS WILL MISS U.S. CHAMPIONSHIPS.
newsitem.headline: ATHLETICS-SUPERSTARS WILL MISS U.S. CHAMPIONSHIPS.

text.p: Several world-class athletes, including Olympic stars Michael Johnson and Carl Lewis, will be missing when the U.S. national championships start here on Wednesday.
Big attractions Johnson and Lewis won't even be in town, and world record-holders Dan O'Brien and Mike Powell have bowed out because they, like Johnson, are injured.

Mary Slaney, the queen of American runners, also is unlikely to participate, but not by choice. The 38-year-old Slaney is under IAAF suspension for a doping test at last year's Olympic trials, and U.S. officials are not expected to defy the IAAF edict although they have not suspended her.
Against this background of intrigue and uncertainty, American athletics is likely to experience the beginning of a changing of the guard, coaches and officials say.

While Olympic champions Allen Johnson, Derrick Adkins, Charles Austin, Kenny Harrison, Randy Barnes and Gail Devers and women's 400-metre world record holder Kim Batten seem certain to secure world championships berths in the five-day qualifier, new faces also are expected to emerge.
"The first year after the Olympics is always a beginning of the changing of the guard," said Dean Hayes, who will coach the U.S. men in Athens in August.
Traditionally, Hayes figures, "about 30 per cent of the people who made the team last year will make the team this year."
But this year's championships are particularly hard hit, at least in star quality.

Lewis, on the verge of retirement, is skipping the meeting by design, but double Olympic champion Johnson, injured in last week's million-dollar race with Donovan Bailey, had hoped to add another world title.
So had three-time world decathlon champion O'Brien. But under U.S. rules only those who finish in the top three in the American championships are eligible for the world meeting.
Another doubtful entry, defending women's 100-metre champion Gwen Torrence, has decided to compete despite knee and leg problems. But she will run only the 200-metres.

Three-time Olympic finalist Dennis Mitchell says he expects to find a way to make the team despite nagging injuries. Former world record-holder Leroy Burrell and 1992 Olympic 200-metre champion Michael Marsh also expect to be contenders in the 100-metres.
